class.name: Word.ParagraphFormat
class.description: Represents a style of paragraph in a document.

properties.name: alignment
properties.description: Specifies the alignment for the specified paragraphs.

examples.description: Update the paragraph format of a specified style by setting its left indent to 30 and alignment to centered.

properties.name: context
properties.description: The request context associated with the object. This connects the add-in's process to the Office host application's process.

examples.description: Access the request context from a ParagraphFormat object to verify the connection to the Office host application and log its properties.

properties.name: firstLineIndent
properties.description: Specifies the value (in points) for a first line or hanging indent. Use a positive value to set a first-line indent, and use a negative value to set a hanging indent.

examples.description: Set a first-line indent of 36 points for the first paragraph in the document

properties.name: keepTogether
properties.description: Specifies whether all lines in the specified paragraphs remain on the same page when Microsoft Word repaginates the document.

examples.description: Keep all lines of the first paragraph together on the same page to prevent it from being split across pages during repagination

properties.name: keepWithNext
properties.description: Specifies whether the specified paragraph remains on the same page as the paragraph that follows it when Microsoft Word repaginates the document.

examples.description: Keep the selected paragraph together with the next paragraph when Word repaginates the document to prevent them from being split across pages.
Modify a style's paragraph format by setting the left indent to 30 points and the alignment to centered.

properties.name: lineSpacing
properties.description: Specifies the line spacing (in points) for the specified paragraphs.

examples.description: Set the line spacing to 18 points for the first paragraph in the document

properties.name: lineUnitAfter
properties.description: Specifies the amount of spacing (in gridlines) after the specified paragraphs.

examples.description: Set the spacing after a paragraph to 2 gridlines to add vertical space between paragraphs in a document

properties.name: lineUnitBefore
properties.description: Specifies the amount of spacing (in gridlines) before the specified paragraphs.

examples.description: Set the spacing before a paragraph to 2 gridlines to create vertical space above it

properties.name: mirrorIndents
properties.description: Specifies whether left and right indents are the same width.

examples.description: Set mirror indents on the first paragraph so that left and right indents have the same width

properties.name: outlineLevel
properties.description: Specifies the outline level for the specified paragraphs.

examples.description: Set the outline level of the first paragraph to Level 2 to organize document structure for navigation and table of contents.

properties.name: rightIndent
properties.description: Specifies the right indent (in points) for the specified paragraphs.

examples.description: Set the right indent of the first paragraph to 36 points (0.5 inches) to create a narrower text margin on the right side.

properties.name: spaceAfter
properties.description: Specifies the amount of spacing (in points) after the specified paragraph or text column.

examples.description: Set the spacing after a paragraph to 12 points to add vertical space between paragraphs

properties.name: spaceBefore
properties.description: Specifies the spacing (in points) before the specified paragraphs.

examples.description: Set the spacing before a paragraph to 12 points to add space above it

properties.name: widowControl
properties.description: Specifies whether the first and last lines in the specified paragraph remain on the same page as the rest of the paragraph when Microsoft Word repaginates the document.

examples.description: Disable widow control for the first paragraph to allow its first and last lines to appear on different pages when Word repaginates the document

methods.name: load
methods.description: Queues up a command to load the specified properties of the object. You must call context.sync() before reading the properties.

params.name: options
params.description: Provides options for which properties of the object to load.

params.name: propertyNames
params.description: A comma-delimited string or an array of strings that specify the properties to load.

params.name: propertyNamesAndPaths
params.description: `propertyNamesAndPaths.select` is a comma-delimited string that specifies the properties to load, and `propertyNamesAndPaths.expand` is a comma-delimited string that specifies the navigation properties to load.

examples.description: Read and display the alignment and indentation properties of the first paragraph in the document

methods.name: set
methods.description: Sets multiple properties of an object at the same time. You can pass either a plain object with the appropriate properties, or another API object of the same type.

params.name: properties
params.description: A JavaScript object with properties that are structured isomorphically to the properties of the object on which the method is called.

params.name: options
params.description: Provides an option to suppress errors if the properties object tries to set any read-only properties.

examples.description: Format the first paragraph by setting multiple properties at once including alignment, indentation, and spacing

methods.name: toJSON
methods.description: Overrides the JavaScript toJSON() method in order to provide more useful output when an API object is passed to JSON.stringify(). (JSON.stringify, in turn, calls the toJSON method of the object that's passed to it.) Whereas the original Word.ParagraphFormat object is an API object, the toJSON method returns a plain JavaScript object (typed as Word.Interfaces.ParagraphFormatData) that contains shallow copies of any loaded child properties from the original object.

examples.description: Serialize paragraph format properties to JSON for logging or storage purposes

methods.name: track
methods.description: Track the object for automatic adjustment based on surrounding changes in the document. This call is a shorthand for context.trackedObjects.add(thisObject). If you're using this object across .sync calls and outside the sequential execution of a ".run" batch, and get an "InvalidObjectPath" error when setting a property or invoking a method on the object, you need to add the object to the tracked object collection when the object was first created. If this object is part of a collection, you should also track the parent collection.

examples.description: Track a paragraph's format object across multiple sync calls to monitor and preserve its alignment changes without encountering InvalidObjectPath errors.

methods.name: untrack
methods.description: Release the memory associated with this object, if it has previously been tracked. This call is shorthand for context.trackedObjects.remove(thisObject). Having many tracked objects slows down the host application, so please remember to free any objects you add, once you're done using them. You'll need to call context.sync() before the memory release takes effect.

examples.description: Format a paragraph and then release it from memory tracking to optimize performance after the formatting is complete.
